title: 106_hr1942
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so we will focus on summarizing the curr_chunk:

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS."

Summarized: Section 1 presents the findings. The Congress finds that free trade agreements improve income and prosperity by increasing competition, eliminating inefficiencies, and lowering costs for manufacturers and consumers. APEC's 21 member economies, representing over half of world production and global trade, are committed to achieving "free and open trade" by 2020 for developing countries and by 2010 for developed countries. The United States has a commitment to achieving free and open trade in the Pacific Rim region by 2020 for developing countries and by 2010 for developed countries. This is crucial for economic growth, creating new trade opportunities, and reducing trade barriers. The financial crisis in Asia has caused significant disruptions. The financial crisis in Asia has disrupted the rapid growth of US exports to the region from 1989-1997. Free trade agreement negotiations are crucial in the current world economy to counter protectionist policies and open markets for US goods and services. Building closer ties with countries like New Zealand, Australia, and Singapore, who are long-time allies of the United States in trade liberalization efforts, will provide leverage for market opening measures for US goods and services. This coordination will be beneficial as trade negotiations for liberalization progress in the next century. The United States must continue promoting its interests in the Asia-Pacific region through aggressive trade negotiations to achieve liberalization. Bilateral trade agreement talks have a positive impact on multilateral and regional trade discussions by expanding common areas of agreement on trade disciplines. Trade and investment disputes between the United States and Pacific Rim countries could be more effectively resolved through mutually agreed-upon disciplines and dispute settlement mechanisms in free trade agreements. This approach would provide a firm foundation for enhanced cooperation and avoid issue-by-issue confrontations under trade remedy laws. Free trade agreements between the United States and Pacific Rim countries will enhance cooperation and market access, stabilizing the bilateral trade balance. The United States trade policy with eligible Pacific Rim countries is outlined in Section 2. The United States aims to eliminate tariff and nontariff barriers through bilateral free trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries. Nontariff barriers include regulatory obstacles, denial of national treatment for services and foreign investment, and inadequate protection for intellectual property rights. The United States aims to eliminate nontariff barriers such as inadequate protection for intellectual property rights, arbitrary standards, and unfair trade practices. SEC. 3. PRENEGOTIATION CONSULTATIONS. Within 60 days of enacting the Act, the President will identify and consult with eligible Pacific Rim countries. If deemed feasible, a ministerial meeting will be requested to discuss the conditions for starting formal negotiations on a free trade agreement. The President will consult with eligible Pacific Rim countries to discuss conditions for starting formal negotiations on a free trade agreement. Within 6 months of each ministerial meeting, the US International Trade Commission will advise the President on the economic effects of providing duty-free treatment for products from that country on US industries and consumers. SEC. 4. MINISTERIAL MEETING RECOMMENDATIONS. The President recommends establishing a council of public and private sector officials to review aspects of the bilateral relationship for a free trade agreement. This includes analyzing trade and investment practices, customs laws, and harmonizing economic data. The council will review trade and investment practices, customs laws, harmonize economic data, and report on the overall bilateral relationship within 6 months. The council will review trade and investment practices, customs laws, harmonize economic data, and report on the overall bilateral relationship within 6 months, concluding a free trade agreement and examining appropriate dispute settlement mechanisms for resolving trade problems. The council will review trade and investment practices, customs laws, harmonize economic data, and report on the overall bilateral relationship within 6 months, concluding a free trade agreement and examining appropriate dispute settlement mechanisms for resolving trade problems. Presidential determination on negotiating free trade agreements with eligible countries. The President will make a determination on the feasibility of starting formal negotiations for a free trade agreement with a Pacific Rim country within 6 months of receiving a report from a bilateral council. The President will determine the feasibility of negotiating a free trade agreement with a Pacific Rim country based on factors like WTO membership and interest in bilateral trade agreements with the US. The country is a member of the World Trade Organization and has shown interest in negotiating a bilateral free trade agreement with the United States. It has implemented trade liberalization and economic reforms to achieve a market-driven economy, demonstrating alignment with US trade policy objectives. The country has demonstrated a commitment to US trade policy objectives and initiatives, actively participating in preparations for the World Trade Organization Ministerial Conference. They are working to eliminate export performance requirements and local content requirements. The organization is focused on eliminating export performance requirements, harmonizing domestic and international standards, increasing economic opportunities for small- and medium-sized businesses, removing barriers to trade in services, providing national treatment for foreign direct investment, and accommodating market access. The country is working to resolve trade disputes with the United States and improve dispute settlement mechanisms, benefiting from enhanced market access for US products and services. The country aims to enhance market access for US products and services by eliminating trade barriers and improving dispute settlement mechanisms. The President must consult regularly with the House Committee on Ways and Means and the Senate Committee on Finance regarding the implementation of the Act. The Act defines "eligible Pacific Rim country" as a WTO member and a member economy of APEC.
